### Problem Description:
You’re coordinating a series of eight graduate workshops across two days.
Each workshop focuses on one of three subjects: Artificial Intelligence
(AI), Mathematics, or Biology. The event spans two full days, and each
day is divided into three time slots: morning, midday, and afternoon.
You have access to three rooms where these workshops can be held.
Every workshop must be placed somewhere in the schedule — that is,
assigned to at least one session at a specific room and a specific time on
one of the two days.
No two workshops can occupy the same room at the same time, and each
room is limited to a maximum of two workshops per day. So, on any
given day, each room will have at least one unused time slot.
However, one of the rooms comes with a constraint: Room 2 is unavailable
in the afternoon, on both days. You’ll need to avoid scheduling anything
there during that time.
Topic-specific requirements further shape the schedule. AI workshops must
always be held in the morning, so they cannot be scheduled at midday or
in the afternoon. Math workshops must not overlap with each other in
time, meaning that no two math sessions can occur simultaneously
 — even if they’re in different rooms. In addition, AI and Biology
workshops must not share a room on the same day. If an AI session
takes place in a given room on a given day, then no Biology session
can be placed in that room on that day, and vice versa.
Finally, to ensure balanced subject coverage, each day must include at
least one workshop from each topic — AI, Math, and Bio — so no subject
is omitted from a day’s agenda.
When choosing among valid schedules, it’s preferable to use space
efficiently: try to fill as many available slots as possible while
respecting all the constraints. The fewer unused room-times, the better.
Implement: There are 8 graduate workshops.
workshop(1..8).
Implement: Workshops are in AI, Math, or Bio.

topic("AI"; "Math"; "Bio").
1 {topicOf(W, T) : topic(T)} 1 :- workshop(W).
Implement: There are 2 days, with 3 time slots per day: morning, midday, and afternoon.

day(1..2).
slot("morning"; "midday"; "afternoon").
Implement: There are 3 rooms.
Implement: Each workshop must be scheduled.
1 {scheduled(W, R, S, D) : room(R), slot(S), day(D)} :- workshop(W).
Implement: Only one workshop can be in a room at a time.
:- scheduled(W1, R, S, D), scheduled(W2, R, S, D), W1 != W2.
Implement: Each room can be used at most twice per day.
{scheduled(W, R, S, D) : workshop(W), slot(S)} 2 :- room(R), day(D).
Implement: Room 2 is not available in the afternoon.
:- scheduled(_, 2, "afternoon", _).
Implement: AI workshops must be in the morning.
:- scheduled(W, _, S, _), topicOf(W, "AI"), S != "morning".
Implement: No two Math workshops can be scheduled at the same time.
:- scheduled(W1, _, S, D), scheduled(W2, _, S, D), topicOf(W1, "Math"), topicOf(W2, "Math"), W1 != W2.

Implement: At least one workshop of each topic must be held on each day.
:- day(D), topic(T), not scheduled(W, _, _, D) : topicOf(W, T).
Implement: Try to minimize idle room slots.

used(R, S, D) :- scheduled(_, R, S, D).
idle(R, S, D) :- room(R), slot(S), day(D), not used(R, S, D).
#minimize {1, R, S, D : idle(R, S, D)}.

ten seminars, each devoted to one of four fields—Artificial Intelligence,
Biology, Mathematics, or Chemistry. Both days are sliced into four
segments — morning, late morning, early afternoon, and late afternoon — and
you have five distinct rooms at your disposal.
Naturally, every seminar must find its place in the programme, and no room ever
hosts more than one talk at once. To keep the flow manageable and give each
room a little breathing room, no room may be booked for more than half of the 
time slots in a single day, nor may it run back‑to‑back sessions without a break.
Also, bear in mind that Room 3 goes offline once afternoon begins,
and Room 5 lacks any projection equipment, so any seminar requiring slides
won’t fit there.
Speaking of equipment, both AI and Mathematics talks rely on a working projector,
and the AI presentations have an early‑day preference: they’re confined to the
morning or late‑morning slots. Biology seminars, by contrast, must be sprinkled
across the two days — never exclusively in one — and you cannot have two bio talks
taking place simultaneously. Chemistry talks, on the other hand, are social
in time but solitary in space: no two of them may ever occupy the same
room. Additionally, you can’t mix a Bio session with a Chem
session under the same roof on a given day, so those pairings must stay apart.
There’s also a special framing requirement: the symposium must open and close
with mathematics, so the very first seminar and the final seminar of are both
mathematics events. Beyond that, you’ll want to avoid empty slots
unless there’s simply no alternative. Each time segment should showcase as
many different topics as possible, and while it’s fine for Biology and Chemistry
to overlap with other sessions, no more than two Bio‑or‑Chem seminars may ever
run at the same moment.
With these guidelines in mind, you’ll blend room capacities, projector access, 
temporal preferences, and topic distributions into a single, seamless schedule 
that serves presenters, attendees, and the venues’ technical quirks without leaving
unnecessary gaps.

rover starts with only 6 units. The inspection at RelayStation offers a diagnostic
reward, but only if all mandatory inspections are completed with more than two battery
units remaining. The map is as follows: BaseCamp connects to Fork1 and Fork2. Fork1
connects to OutpostX and RelayStation. Fork2 connects to OutpostY and RelayStation.

If you pick a CPU worth more than $500, you can’t pair it with the Pixie GPU.
Avoid configurations where the performance spread (max - min) exceeds 50 points.
If you select the FlashNova SSD, the GPU must score at least 100.
You must select exactly two components whose price is above $300 and the GPU’s performance
must fall between the CPU and drive—i.e., not the highest or lowest.
